an4.39:1.1: Then Ujjaya the brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
an4.39:1.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:
an4.39:1.5: Nor do I criticize all sacrifices.
an4.39:1.6: Take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are slaughtered.
an4.39:1.7: I criticize that kind of violent sacrifice.
an4.39:1.9: Because neither perfected ones nor those who have entered the path to perfection will attend such a violent sacrifice.
an4.39:2.1: But take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are not slaughtered.
an4.39:2.2: I praise that kind of non-violent sacrifice; for example, a regular gift as an ongoing family sacrifice.
an4.39:2.4: Because perfected ones and those who have entered the path to perfection will attend such a non-violent sacrifice.
an4.39:3.4: these huge violent sacrifices yield no great fruit.
an4.39:4.1: The great sages of good conduct
an4.39:5.1: But the great sages of good conduct
an4.39:6.1: An intelligent person should sacrifice like this,
an4.39:6.2: for this sacrifice is very fruitful.
an4.39:6.3: For a sponsor of sacrifices like this,
an4.39:6.5: Such a sacrifice is truly abundant,
an4.39:6.6: and even the deities are pleased.”
